data.title: The Impact of the American Dream on Modern Society

data.text:
1. Introduction

På det amerikanske samfund har den amerikanske drøm haft en betydelig indflydelse gennem historien. Denne rapport vil udforske, hvordan ideen om den amerikanske drøm har formet moderne samfund og kultur. Vi vil undersøge den historiske udvikling af denne idé samt identificere de centrale komponenter af den amerikanske drøm. Derudover vil vi analysere, hvordan den amerikanske drøm afspejles i litteratur og populærkultur, samt udfordringer og kritik af denne idé. Endelig vil vi se på forholdet mellem den amerikanske drøm og social mobilitet, samt diskutere de fremtidige implikationer af denne idé i moderne samfund.

2. Historical Development of the American Dream

Den historiske udvikling af den amerikanske drøm kan spores tilbage til den koloniale æra, hvor ideen om social mobilitet og muligheden for at opnå succes gennem hårdt arbejde begyndte at tage form. I det 19. århundrede blev Amerika set som et sted, hvor enhver kunne skabe deres egen skæbne gennem dedikation og tro på drømmen om bedre levevilkår. Den industrielle revolution og tilstedeværelsen af ubegrænsede muligheder tiltrak folk fra hele verden til landet. Siden da har den amerikanske drøm udviklet sig i takt med politiske, sociale og økonomiske ændringer, og har været et centralt tema i den amerikanske kultur og samfundsliv.

3. Key Components of the American Dream

De centrale komponenter i den amerikanske drøm omfatter muligheden for økonomisk succes gennem hårdt arbejde, personlig frihed til at forfølge ens egne mål og ambitioner, og muligheden for at skabe et bedre liv for ens børn. Økonomisk succes er et vigtigt element, idet den amerikanske drøm ofte er forbundet med idéen om at opnå velstand og materielle ejendele som et symbol på succes. Personlig frihed spiller også en afgørende rolle, da det giver enkeltpersoner mulighed for at forfølge deres egne drømme og mål uden begrænsninger. Endelig er ønsket om at kunne give ens børn en bedre fremtid og adgang til uddannelse og muligheder også en central komponent i den amerikanske drøm.

4. The American Dream in Literature and Popular Culture

Literature serves to reflect society and educate future generations about the values and beliefs of their ancestors. It is a known historical fact that no other force can change society as much as literature does, because a reader's mind gets enriched with the ideas and moral values conveyed through a literary work. Although literature is not something one can rely on when discussing facts and data like an encyclopedia, as long as works of literature reflect a society's ideas and moral values, they may serve as a potential source of information. The American community has always had to deal with the concept of the Dream to some extent. It was with the early European settlers that the idea of a Dream became a useful concept driven by an expectation of success. Guy de Maupassant, in his two short stories "The Necklace" and "The Piece of String," illustrates the problem of not being able to fulfill a perfect, desired life in a dramatic way. These fictional stories paint a perfect, detailed picture of the society where pride, appearance, and luck play a big part in how people are judged, and in which the discussion of poverty-related issues has a lot of negative effects and a short life. In 1925, an American writer, F. Scott Fitzgerald, wrote a novel called "The Great Gatsby," which is the most famous example of the American Dream in the world. This work is written during a time when the collapse of a perfect, desired life seems to take place. This piece of literature shows a perfect life, the beauty of romantic relations, loyalty, eternity, and great wealth valued by society.

5. Challenges and Critiques of the American Dream

Udfordringerne og kritikken af den amerikanske drøm udpeger en række problemer, herunder ulighed, social uretfærdighed og manglende ligestilling. Mange kritikere hævder, at den amerikanske drøm er uopnåelig for mange, især dem fra lavere socioøkonomiske baggrunde. Desuden hævdes det, at den amerikanske drøm kan føre til materialisme og manglende fokus på vigtige livsværdier. Kritikere peger også på, at den amerikanske drøm er baseret på individualisme snarere end fællesskab, hvilket kan resultere i isolation og mangel på socialt ansvar. Disse udfordringer og kritikker rejser vigtige spørgsmål omkring den amerikanske drøms bæredygtighed og dens indvirkning på samfundet i dag.

6. The American Dream and Social Mobility

Long treated as the cornerstone of American society, the American Dream is increasingly coming to be seen as a socially divisive element in the wider debate about the functioning of U.S. society. Although it springs from the individual, its fulfillment not only benefits the individual, but also the wider society. Whether it is individuals or the wider society that gets priority treatment within U.S. society—not to mention the mechanism for pursuing it—remains at the crux of the debate. Social mobility may stymie the individual, his community, or the wider society, but it is vital toward the long-term growth of the country's capitalist system. However, how much longer will that importance prevail, and what lengths should U.S. society go to in order to facilitate it? Creating a level playing field has been at the heart of the argument for generations. Although the rewards for reintroducing it may be great, the costs are not trivial either. The reward is that it would rightly encourage more communities, labor markets, services, and education to offer role models vital to social and economic advancement. The negative, however, would be that it could potentially halt U.S. innovation: individuals wanting to become entrepreneurs may cease to chase their dreams.

7. Conclusion and Future Implications

This chapter aims to highlight both the positive and negative implications associated with the American Dream. Discussion of these implications leads to the unveiling of potential concerns, both in terms of the ideology's ability to provide sustainable development and the philosophical postulates. Some might argue that in contemporary America, the American Dream no longer represents the "American Way," and we would very much agree with such a premise. In fact, Ragni (2000) and also Nuccio (2005) argue that stable government, peace, and security are the American Way, and not necessarily "access-to-opportunity." We believe many sides of this issue deserve to be further investigated. For instance, research has yet to explore ways in which criminal deterrents play a role in the economy and ultimate success of a democratic process. Future implications suggest that government enactment of changes in law and policy under the auspices of the American Dream has created a government spending level unmatched by revenue from taxes. As outlined earlier, this has ultimately resulted in a large deficit with both current and future potential effects. Moreover, a main concern also arises in terms of the incapacities rooted in the premise. Just as the Italian Judiciary in a 2003 decision against the Fiat Company noted, "the successful outcome of the economic processes to which the automaker proposes to steer its 50,000 workers should not lead to impairing those rights which are also founded on the basis of the adverse circumstances which have been encountered." I believe a shift towards a state whereby rights are granted according to identity and not as an inevitable outcome of processes towards which individuals contribute, at the expense of a loss of incentives for those that undertake a role in that given process, must be avoided.
